dialogue: At least tell the child you're leaving.
He knows if you've been bad or good, so be good for goodness sake-
Nanna!
...you better not cry, you better not pout, I'm tellin' you why..
Hmm. Coulda sworn I heard... Must be mice.
Nanna. Nanna. Harriet!
El...
Shhh... I ain't going nowhere, baby.
...I hope it's a good photograph of him at least? I'm not reading The Register, they haven't said one right thing about these protests.
Has everyone in Leon County gone crazy? Course I'm proud he was there! Evelyn'd be proud, too. You know that theater was showing The Ugly American and Invaders from Mars? Now ain't that something?
Nanna, next time I want to do the civil disobedience part.
I love you Elwood.
I love you, too, Nanna.
You hungry?
No, I'm okay.
Put it back.
Put it back.
Ok...shh now. Hold still. They got you good.
Ow.
Nanna-
Not Elwood, Lord.
Nanna, I'll be back soon.
Yeah? Look what Mr. Hill brought you.
Ain't that nice? ... Sit down, have some cake with Nanna.
Lyndon Johnson's carrying on President Kennedy's civil rights bill. And if that good old boy is doing right, you know things is changing. Be a whole different thing when you come home, Elwood.
You pick up right where you left off, with no more hassle.
Huh, yeah.
I'm sure Melvin Briggs will have you. And those books you were reading ain't gone nowhere.
Hmm.

I've been taking less work and spending more time at the church. And I told the trash men to be careful with that big truck, the way they block the road and so early in the morning, when you can really hear everyone get out of bed. Well not everybody. The house across the way burned down. Burned a whole day straight. The smoke was something awful.
El, he's gone. Mr. Andrews, you know, our lawyer who's so optimistic about your appeal- I went downtown to see him, I took the bus. I had paid him $200 which wasn't enough.
But he was so adamant persuasive with Mr. Marconi that he and his wife kicked in another $100, and then that was all right.
You mean he's gone... he didn't... after all this time...
The landlord was showing the office to a dentist. When I asked for Mr. Andrews they just looked through me like I wasn't there neither. He picked up stakes to Atlanta without a word.
He took that $300. And he knows, he said, what we got on our hands is a "classic miscarriage of justice". I know we hoped to have you out of here by now and I think...
It's okay, Nanna.
I let you down, El.
I'm okay Nanna. I'm hanging in there.
You got any friends? How about Turner?
Turner? How d'you-
I didn't know how I was gonna get you that package, that day-
-and there he was. I like him, he's polite, looked me in the eye. That was a real kindness...
